Award.AwardTitle: Cognitive, Strategic, and Relational Drivers of Organizational Effectiveness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study aims to shed light on how interactions across different levels (individual, group and network) affect organizational effectiveness. Drawing on four research streams within the organization sciences -- strategic leadership, group processes, inter-organizational social networks, and competitive dynamics -- it addresses three questions: How do the characteristics of management teams influence the nature and structure of the relationships their organizations form with other organizations and entities? How do these relationships enhance (or constrain) an organization's capabilities for strategic or operational innovations? How does an organization's approach to decision making, strategic planning, and teamwork influence innovation and effectiveness?
The study sample consists of a set of economic development organizations (EDOs) in an economically distressed region of Kentucky. Methods include ethnographic interviews, data gathering from archival sources and web-based surveys, social network analysis and sequence analysis. Findings will contribute to our scientific understanding of organizational effectiveness and innovation. They will also have practical implications for enhancing effectiveness of EDO's in Kentucky. These will be shared with managers and policy makers so as to ensure maximal positive broader impacts from the work.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaboration is essential to innovation, and is often a key driver of organizational performance. Companies, government agencies, nonprofits, and all other types of organizations have goals that can be better accomplished with the aid and cooperation of other organizations. Collaboration is often not enough, however, to achieve an organization's goals for effectiveness and performance. Entrepreneurial orientation (EO) has also been identified as a key driver of effectiveness in a variety of contexts. EO is defined organization's decision-making tendency to engage in new, innovative, and entrepreneurial activities.

This project provides evidence that EO and collaborative strategies are inherently intertwined, and together interactively influence organizational performance. We test these ideas on a sample of 83 economic development organizations (EDOs) that operate in the persistently distressed region of eastern Kentucky. We define EDOs broadly as nonprofit organizations that direct a majority of their resources to the goal of local economic development. With the aid of the social network perspective, we define a collaborative network as the local, ego-centric collaborative network of a focal organization. 

In the context of EDOs operating in the rural region of eastern Kentucky, we predicted that an EO to be vital for organizational performance. Also, it is important for EDOs to establish and work within a collaborate network consisting of other EDOs that, together, provide a wide range of services and cover greater geographic areas. 

Data for this study were collected through an online survey that we created and sent to over 200 EDO leaders. Our analysis is based on 98 completed surveys. The survey enabled us to measure each EDO’s level of EO, collaborate network size and heterogeneity (service diversity), and both perceived and self-reported EDO effectiveness. 

We used several forms of statistical analysis to test our predictions and report our strongest regression results in the attached image. We found that higher levels of entrepreneurial orientation (EO) is positively related to EDO performance and effectiveness. We also found that two attributes of the EDO’s collaborate network (network size and network heterogeneity) are also positively related to EDO performance. Our results also reveal some interesting interactions between EO and network attributes and performance. As depicted in one attached image, EDOs that have smaller than average can compensate for this apparent lack of collaborative embeddedness by exhibiting higher levels of EO. The other attached image shows a similar result with respect to the interaction between EO, network heterogeneity, and EDO effectiveness.

This study integrates research in EO and interorganizational collaboration by examining the interrelationships between EO, collaborative networks, and organizational performance in a context particularly well-suited to do so. We predicted and found that EO moderates the relationship between collaborative network properties and performance, such that organizations with small and less heterogeneous networks reap higher gains to performance than those with larger and more heterogeneous networks. We believe that our findings can benefit small, non-profit, volunteer organizations that have important service missions, yet are, on average, resource- and capability-poor. We found that service organizations that have a palpable entrepreneurial spirit that are also embedded in collaborative networks can enjoy higher levels of success and effectiveness relative to organizations that are inertia, stale, and opt to go it alone.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2013
Modified by: Walter J Ferrier
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Collaboration is essential to innovation, and is often a key driver of organizational performance. Companies, government agencies, nonprofits, and all other types of organizations have goals that can be better accomplished with the aid and cooperation of other organizations. Collaboration is often not enough, however, to achieve an organization's goals for effectiveness and performance. Entrepreneurial orientation (EO) has also been identified as a key driver of effectiveness in a variety of contexts. EO is defined organization's decision-making tendency to engage in new, innovative, and entrepreneurial activities. This project provides evidence that EO and collaborative strategies are inherently intertwined, and together interactively influence organizational performance. We test these ideas on a sample of 83 economic development organizations (EDOs) that operate in the persistently distressed region of eastern Kentucky. We define EDOs broadly as nonprofit organizations that direct a majority of their resources to the goal of local economic development. In the context of EDOs operating in the rural region of eastern Kentucky, we predicted that an EO to be vital for organizational performance. Also, it is important for EDOs to establish and work within a collaborate network consisting of other EDOs that, together, provide a wide range of services and cover greater geographic areas. Data for this study were collected through an online survey that we created and sent to over 200 EDO leaders. Our analysis is based on 98 completed surveys. The survey enabled us to measure each EDOÆs level of EO, collaborate network size and heterogeneity (service diversity), and both perceived and self-reported EDO effectiveness. We used several forms of statistical analysis to test our predictions and report our strongest regression results in the attached image. We found that higher levels of entrepreneurial orientation (EO) is positively related to EDO performance and effectiveness. We also found that two attributes of the EDOÆs collaborate network (network size and network heterogeneity) are also positively related to EDO performance. Our results also reveal some interesting interactions between EO and network attributes and performance. As depicted in one attached image, EDOs that have smaller than average can compensate for this apparent lack of collaborative embeddedness by exhibiting higher levels of EO. The other attached image shows a similar result with respect to the interaction between EO, network heterogeneity, and EDO effectiveness. This study integrates research in EO and interorganizational collaboration by examining the interrelationships between EO, collaborative networks, and organizational performance in a context particularly well-suited to do so. We predicted and found that EO moderates the relationship between collaborative network properties and performance, such that organizations with small and less heterogeneous networks reap higher gains to performance than those with larger and more heterogeneous networks. We believe that our findings can benefit small, non-profit, volunteer organizations that have important service missions, yet are, on average, resource- and capability-poor. We found that service organizations that have a palpable entrepreneurial spirit that are also embedded in collaborative networks can enjoy higher levels of success and effectiveness relative to organizations that are inertia, stale, and opt to go it alone.
